stem: A mass casualty incident has occurred at a local concert venue. As the triage nurse, categorize the following clients based on the START triage system. Select one triage category for each client.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
08:00 Initial report: Explosion at concert venue, multiple casualties. EMS en route. 

08:05 Receiving first wave of patients. Prioritizing based on obvious injuries and responsiveness.

08:10 Pt A: ~30yo male, RR 32, radial pulse present, follows simple commands. Multiple lacerations.

08:12 Pt B: ~60yo female, RR 10, radial pulse absent, does not respond to verbal stimuli. Open head wound.

08:15 Pt C: ~25yo female, RR 24, radial pulse present, unable to walk, femur fracture suspected.

08:18 Pt D: ~40yo male, RR 0 after repositioning airway and opening mouth, no pulse. 

08:20 Pt E: ~10yo male, RR 28, radial pulse present, anxious, multiple abrasions, able to walk.

08:25 Resources stretched. Requesting additional personnel and supplies. Maintaining focus on rapid assessment and triage. Continuous reassessment of patients is ongoing.

rationale.correct: Correct answers are based on the START triage algorithm, which prioritizes patients based on respiration, perfusion, and mental status. Red (Immediate) are for those requiring immediate intervention to survive. Yellow (Delayed) are for those with serious but not immediately life-threatening injuries. Green (Minor) are for the 'walking wounded'. Black (Expectant) are for those unlikely to survive given available resources.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect answers represent misapplication of the START triage algorithm, potentially leading to inappropriate allocation of resources and compromised patient outcomes.

answerBreakdown.text: Patient A: ~30yo male, RR 32, radial pulse present, follows simple commands. Multiple lacerations.
answerBreakdown.rationale: The patient has a respiratory rate > 30, which automatically classifies them as immediate (Red) according to START triage.

answerBreakdown.text: Patient B: ~60yo female, RR 10, radial pulse absent, does not respond to verbal stimuli. Open head wound.
answerBreakdown.rationale: This patient is unresponsive with absent pulse and spontaneous respirations. Given the limited resources in a mass casualty incident, this patient is classified as expectant (Black).

answerBreakdown.text: Patient C: ~25yo female, RR 24, radial pulse present, unable to walk, femur fracture suspected.
answerBreakdown.rationale: This patient has a palpable radial pulse, is breathing, and follows commands, but unable to walk. Classify as delayed (Yellow).

answerBreakdown.text: Patient D: ~40yo male, RR 0 after repositioning airway and opening mouth, no pulse.
answerBreakdown.rationale: This patient is apneic with no pulse even after airway repositioning. Classify as expectant (Black).

answerBreakdown.text: Patient E: ~10yo male, RR 28, radial pulse present, anxious, multiple abrasions, able to walk.
answerBreakdown.rationale: This patient is able to walk, so is classified as minor (Green).

clinicalPearls: START triage focuses on rapid assessment and categorization to allocate resources effectively during mass casualty incidents.
The ability to follow simple commands is a key determinant in START triage.
Remember to reassess patients regularly as their condition can change rapidly.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing minor injuries with more critical conditions can lead to misclassification and inappropriate resource allocation.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the core START triage criteria (respiration, perfusion, mental status) and prioritize patients with the most life-threatening conditions.
